DOC.HEADLINE: SOCK-LESS COUPLES PUTS BEST FOOT FORWARD

TEXT.P: AUGUSTA, Ga.--Exactly six months earlier, Fred Couples wandered Harding Park in a ceremonial role as U.S. captain in the Presidents Cup. Thursday night, he went to sleep in sole possession of the lead at the Masters.

Couples--at age 50 and wearing tennis shoes with no socks because they help his troublesome back--shot an opening-round 66. It was the best Masters round of his long career, and it gave him a one-shot lead over Tom Watson, Phil Mickelson and three other players.

So maybe success on the Champions Tour, where Couples won his past three starts, does translate to Augusta National. Couples did not sound especially confident earlier this week, saying it would be a "pipe dream" to think he can duplicate his 1992 title.

"Yeah, to win Augusta at age 50 would be a pipe dream," Couples said after needing only 24 putts Thursday. "Can I still win? Of course. It would be a nice dream, for sure, but I've got a lot of golf left to even think about being in contention."

TIGER ON COMMERCIAL: Tiger Woods spoke for the first time about the television advertisement Nike released on the eve of this Masters. In the commercial, a solemn-looking Woods stares straight ahead while the voice of his late father, Earl, asks "Did you learn anything?"

"It's amazing how my dad can speak to me in different ways, even when he's long gone," Woods said. "He's still helping me. Any son who has lost a father, who meant so much in their life, I think they would understand the spot."

BRIEFLY: Mickelson went eagle-birdie-birdies at Nos. 13 through 15 to shoot his 67. ... Y.E. Yang, playing in his first major since he took down Woods in last year's PGA Championship, also shot 67. ... Thanks mostly to friendly pin positions, 16 players posted scores in the 60s and no fewer than 31 broke par. ... On the other end of the spectrum, Jim Furyk and Henrik Stenson each shot 80.
